principle_description: Building teams of passionate missionaries rather than mercenaries
question: Tell me about a time when you joined a project or organization because you deeply believed in its mission, even though other opportunities might have offered better compensation or prestige.
quote: You really want a company full of missionaries, not mercenaries.
source: Sam Altman, CEO, Multiple interviews, 2023

principle_description: Empowering individuals to make decisions while maintaining responsibility for outcomes
question: Tell me about a time when you were given significant autonomy on a project and how you balanced creative freedom with accountability for results.
quote: I believe that individuals excel when they are empowered to make decisions and take ownership of their projects.
source: Sam Altman, CEO, Company leadership interviews, 2023

principle_description: Prioritizing responsible development and societal benefit over rapid advancement
question: Tell me about a time when you had to make a difficult decision that prioritized long-term ethical considerations over short-term gains or competitive pressure.
quote: We're building AGI to be a catalyst for widespread societal benefit, not merely a technological milestone.
source: Sam Altman, CEO, OpenAI Vision statements, 2023

principle_description: Fostering open information flow and feedback loops throughout the organization
question: Tell me about a time when you had to communicate difficult or sensitive information transparently to maintain trust, even when it might have been easier to withhold details.
quote: I advocate for transparency in communication, both in successes and failures, creating a culture where information flows freely.
source: Sam Altman, CEO, Leadership philosophy interviews, 2023

principle_description: Understanding business fundamentals through hands-on experience rather than theory
question: Tell me about a time when you learned something critical about a business or process by doing the actual work yourself, rather than relying on reports or secondhand information.
quote: We believe in learning by doing. I personally drove all DoorDash deliveries for the first year to understand our business.
source: Tony Xu, CEO, Stanford Graduate School of Business, 2023

principle_description: Getting deeply involved in operational details to understand root causes and solutions
question: Tell me about a time when you discovered an important insight by digging into the smallest details of a problem that others had overlooked.
quote: Getting to the lowest level of detail means being students of the business by actually doing the work.
source: Tony Xu, CEO, Stanford Graduate School of Business, 2023

principle_description: Working collaboratively with stakeholders rather than viewing them as adversaries
question: Tell me about a time when you turned a potentially competitive or adversarial relationship into a collaborative partnership that benefited all parties.
quote: If restaurants don't thrive, we cannot.
source: Tony Xu, CEO, COVID-19 response interviews, 2020

principle_description: Prioritizing personal integrity and values over impressive backgrounds or achievements
question: Tell me about a time when you had to make a hiring or team decision where you chose someone with strong character over someone with more impressive credentials.
quote: Character is more important than credentials.
source: Tony Xu, CEO, Leadership philosophy interviews, 2022

principle_description: Solving real customer problems rather than building technology for its own sake
question: Tell me about a time when you identified and solved a genuine customer pain point, even if the solution wasn't the most technically impressive or innovative approach.
quote: We're not just a delivery company. We're a technology company that's reimagining the way people shop for groceries.
source: Apoorva Mehta, Founder, Company vision statements, 2019

principle_description: Challenging conventional approaches to find better solutions
question: Tell me about a time when you questioned the standard way of doing something and found a significantly better approach.
quote: Of course, but maybe - meaning of course that's one way to do it, but maybe we could try it another way.
source: Apoorva Mehta, Founder, Leadership philosophy interviews, 2020

principle_description: Maintaining focus and systematic approach to achieving long-term goals
question: Tell me about a time when you had to maintain discipline and focus on long-term objectives despite short-term pressures or distractions.
quote: When asked how he helped Instacart succeed, Mehta replied simply: Discipline.
source: Apoorva Mehta, Founder, Founder interviews, 2021

principle_description: Putting organizational success ahead of personal interests or recognition
question: Tell me about a time when you had to make a decision that was clearly best for the company, even though it might have limited your personal advancement or recognition.
quote: Think about the big picture: to put the company before themselves, to take the long-term view, and to never be afraid of giving away their legos.
source: Apoorva Mehta, Founder, Leadership advice to team, 2020

principle_description: Focusing on output and impact rather than being physically present or visible
question: Tell me about a time when you delivered exceptional results while working independently, demonstrating your ability to be productive without direct supervision.
quote: In many co-located companies, you can just show up and people will presume you're working, but at GitLab we actually check your output and results.
source: Sid Sijbrandij, CEO, Remote work interviews, 2023

principle_description: Making decisions and moving forward despite imperfect information
question: Tell me about a time when you had to make an important decision quickly with incomplete information and take action to drive results.
quote: Most important, we maintain a bias for action. Everyone at GitLab is empowered to be proactive, creative, and effective.
source: Sid Sijbrandij, CEO, GitLab Handbook, 2023

principle_description: Working effectively across different time zones and communication styles
question: Tell me about a time when you successfully led or contributed to a project where team members were working across different time zones or schedules.
quote: Working remotely is easy. The challenge is working asynchronously.
source: Sid Sijbrandij, CEO, McKinsey interview, 2023

principle_description: Creating systems where information is accessible and decisions are well-documented
question: Tell me about a time when you implemented a system or process that significantly improved information sharing and decision-making transparency in your organization.
quote: Everything we do is documented in our handbook, and there's no secret headquarters where decisions are made.
source: Sid Sijbrandij, CEO, Company culture interviews, 2023

principle_description: Questioning assumptions and building solutions from fundamental truths
question: Tell me about a time when you approached a complex problem by breaking it down to its most basic elements and building a solution from first principles.
quote: Thinking from first principles is what philosophy really teaches you, but it really can be used in a surprising amount of ways.
source: David Hsu, CEO, Operator Playbook interviews, 2022

principle_description: Prioritizing real user problems over impressive technical features
question: Tell me about a time when you chose to build a simple solution that solved a real user problem instead of a more complex or technically impressive feature.
quote: When you build enough internal tools as an engineer, you realize that all internal tools basically look the same.
source: David Hsu, CEO, Retool founding story, 2021

principle_description: Choosing practical solutions that work over impressive but less effective approaches
question: Tell me about a time when you advocated for a practical, straightforward solution over a more prestigious or cutting-edge approach.
quote: We are much more interested in hiring people who are able to figure things out from first principles, rather than 'this is how sales was done at my last company.'
source: David Hsu, CEO, Hiring philosophy interviews, 2022

principle_description: Maintaining rapid pace of execution while preserving quality standards
question: Tell me about a time when you had to significantly accelerate your team's pace of delivery while maintaining quality standards.
quote: I think Retool should be operating substantially faster as a company in all areas, I think in sales, marketing, engineering, everything.
source: David Hsu, CEO, Company scaling interviews, 2023

principle_description: Prioritizing exceptional product quality over rapid feature development
question: Tell me about a time when you insisted on higher quality standards for a deliverable, even when it meant taking more time or resources.
quote: We started with quality. Then we learned that people actually noticed, because it's a rare approach—especially for startups.
source: Karri Saarinen, CEO, First Round interview, 2023

principle_description: Making design and product decisions based on developed judgment rather than solely on metrics
question: Tell me about a time when you made an important decision based on your intuition and experience, despite data or popular opinion suggesting a different approach.
quote: At Linear, we don't make decisions based on data or experiments—including A/B tests. To design with craft, you must develop and trust your intuition.
source: Karri Saarinen, CEO, Design philosophy interviews, 2023

principle_description: Creating tools and processes that empower front-line workers rather than just management
question: Tell me about a time when you designed a solution or process that specifically empowered individual contributors to be more effective in their work.
quote: We felt like current tools were geared toward management and ignored the needs of engineers and designers who actually build things.
source: Karri Saarinen, CEO, Linear product philosophy, 2022

principle_description: Maintaining laser focus on what matters most and saying no to everything else
question: Tell me about a time when you had to maintain extreme focus on the most important priority, even when it meant disappointing stakeholders who wanted other things addressed.
quote: In my experience, you can never have too much focus. I try to always ask, 'What's most important or most meaningful right now?'
source: Karri Saarinen, CEO, Focus philosophy interviews, 2023

principle_description: Prioritizing authentic community needs over business metrics
question: Tell me about a time when you advocated for what was right for users or community members, even when it conflicted with business objectives.
quote: Our mission is bringing community and belonging to everybody in the world.
source: Steve Huffman, CEO, Mission statements, 2023

principle_description: Using core principles to guide difficult choices rather than convenience or expedience
question: Tell me about a time when you used your core values or principles to make a difficult decision, especially when other approaches might have been easier.
quote: Take your decision, try to escalate it to a value or a principle, and then make the decision using that value or principle.
source: Steve Huffman, CEO, Leadership philosophy, 2023

principle_description: Fostering genuine dialogue and diverse perspectives rather than echo chambers
question: Tell me about a time when you facilitated or participated in a difficult conversation with diverse viewpoints, helping people understand each other better.
quote: Since the day we added the commenting feature, Reddit has been home to some of the most authentic conversations you can have online.
source: Steve Huffman, CEO, Community philosophy, 2023

principle_description: Establishing disciplined practices that eventually become natural organizational behavior
question: Tell me about a time when you implemented structured processes that eventually became part of your team's or organization's natural culture.
quote: Process becomes culture - putting discipline and regular practices in place until they become second nature.
source: Steve Huffman, CEO, Culture building interviews, 2023

principle_description: Creating environments where diverse people can participate and thrive
question: Tell me about a time when you took specific actions to make a community or team more inclusive and welcoming to people from different backgrounds.
quote: We embrace inclusion at Twitch because we want to have access to the most competent staff, the most successful content creators, and the largest audience.
source: Emmett Shear, Former CEO, Twitch values document, 2022

principle_description: Using testing and iteration rather than assumptions to make important choices
question: Tell me about a time when you designed and ran experiments to make an important decision, rather than relying on opinions or assumptions.
quote: One of Twitch's favorite values was 'experiment to decide,' which Shear actively lived by in his leadership approach.
source: Emmett Shear, Former CEO, Leadership approach, 2022

principle_description: Starting with ultimate objectives rather than copying existing solutions
question: Tell me about a time when you stepped back to identify the real end goal and found a completely different approach than what was commonly being used.
quote: Before deciding on a course of action, know what ultimate goal you have in mind. Are there alternatives I haven't considered?
source: Emmett Shear, Former CEO, Twitch values document, 2022

principle_description: Empowering teams to act quickly and decisively without excessive approval processes
question: Tell me about a time when you empowered your team to move quickly and make their own decisions, and how you handled the results.
quote: The values focus on what makes Twitch unique and how it encourages its people to move fast, make their own decisions, and do what's right for the company.
source: Emmett Shear, Former CEO, Company values, 2022

principle_description: Ensuring every team member contributes meaningfully rather than just occupying a position
question: Tell me about a time when you identified that someone on your team wasn't contributing effectively and how you addressed the situation.
quote: One of PlanetScale's core values is 'no passengers' - we expect everyone to contribute meaningfully, not tolerating people just sitting around.
source: Sam Lambert, CEO, Company culture interviews, 2023

principle_description: Choosing practical
question: proven solutions over exciting new technologies
question_type: Tell me about a time when you chose a boring, practical solution over a more exciting or trendy approach, and how it benefited the project.
quote: Medium
source: Most successful companies are boring. We avoid 'the new hotness' to build a culture that reflects the often boring decisions that make or break a company.

principle_description: Maintaining consistently high talent and quality bars without compromise
question: Tell me about a time when you had to enforce high standards even when it was difficult or unpopular, and how it impacted team performance.
quote: It comes down to just what you're willing to tolerate or enforce. You set that high and you try not to deviate from it at any point.
source: Sam Lambert, CEO, Team building philosophy, 2023

principle_description: Building followership through competence and good intentions rather than positional power
question: Tell me about a time when you influenced people to follow your direction without having formal authority over them, and what made them choose to follow you.
quote: Being influential requires being competent, knowing what you're talking about, and being good-natured with good intent.
source: Sam Lambert, CEO, Leadership principles, 2023

principle_description: Focusing on real user needs rather than personal preferences or assumptions
question: Tell me about a time when you discovered that what you thought users wanted was different from what they actually needed, and how you adapted.
quote: The number one piece of advice we give at YC is to build something people want.
source: Paul Graham, Co-founder, Y Combinator philosophy, 2005

principle_description: Directly engaging with customers to understand their real problems and needs
question: Tell me about a time when direct conversations with users completely changed your understanding of a problem or led to a breakthrough insight.
quote: Go talk to your users. This is not just a suggestion, it's the most important thing you can do.
source: Paul Graham, Co-founder, Startup advice, 2012

principle_description: Finding ways to overcome obstacles and make progress regardless of constraints
question: Tell me about a time when you faced significant obstacles or resource constraints and found creative ways to achieve your goals anyway.
quote: We look for relentlessly resourceful founders who find a way to make things happen no matter what.
source: Paul Graham, Co-founder, Founder qualities, 2009

principle_description: Getting products to users quickly and improving based on real feedback
question: Tell me about a time when you launched something before it felt completely ready, and how you used user feedback to rapidly improve it.
quote: Launch now. Whatever you're thinking about doing, you can probably do it faster.
source: Paul Graham, Co-founder, Launch advice, 2012

principle_description: Creating spaces where people feel genuine connection and acceptance
question: Tell me about a time when you helped create or improve a community where people felt like they truly belonged.
quote: We want to create a place where everyone can find belonging.
source: Jason Citron, CEO, Discord mission, 2021

principle_description: Continuously improving products based on deep user engagement and feedback
question: Tell me about a time when passionate user feedback led you to make significant improvements to something you were working on.
quote: We keep iterating until our users don't just like our product, they love it.
source: Jason Citron, CEO, Product philosophy, 2020

principle_description: Achieving significant results with lean
question: focused teams rather than large organizations
question_type: Tell me about a time when you accomplished something significant with a small, focused team that might typically require many more resources.
quote: Medium
source: We believe small teams can have huge impact when they're focused and move quickly.

principle_description: Prioritizing sustainable community growth over short-term engagement metrics
question: Tell me about a time when you made decisions that prioritized long-term relationship building over immediate results or metrics.
quote: We're not optimizing for time spent or engagement metrics. We're optimizing for meaningful relationships.
source: Jason Citron, CEO, Platform philosophy, 2022

principle_description: Working on projects that expand online economic activity and opportunity
question: Tell me about a time when you worked on something that helped expand economic opportunities or made it easier for others to conduct business.
quote: Our mission is to increase the GDP of the internet.
source: Patrick Collison, CEO, Company mission, 2010

principle_description: Prioritizing the experience of people who build with your tools or products
question: Tell me about a time when you significantly improved the experience for people who had to use or integrate with something you built.
quote: We obsess over making our APIs beautiful and our developer experience exceptional.
source: Patrick Collison, CEO, Developer philosophy, 2015

principle_description: Building solutions that work reliably across different countries and systems
question: Tell me about a time when you designed or built something that had to work reliably across different regions, regulations, or technical environments.
quote: We're building the infrastructure that powers online commerce globally.
source: Patrick Collison, CEO, Infrastructure vision, 2018
